review_title: It's a fun Star Wars game with some flaw
one_reviews_text: The story is ok, they introduce this cool "command your army" mechanic and then use it once, pushing buttons on the ship is cool but it only lasts for a minute or two, theres no moving in combat, so melee enemies can be taking out by melee, and ranged characters can be taken out by ranged. You wanna stab a stormtrooper? Too bad. You wanna dodge a lightsaber attack and then stab them in the back? Too bad. If the game THINKS a blast hit you, you lose health. Sometimes melee weapons just, phase through the lightsaber, or debris/lightsaber throws don't do anything after making direct and clear contact. Other than those bugs the game's lightsabers, action, dojo, and force mechanics are pretty good.

Let's be clear. THIS IS NOT A GAME!  This is a 3D movie with “gameplay” sprinkled in. I use gameplay lightly because there are no consequences and your actions are pretty much meaningless. It’s supposed to be thrilling, but I’m not sure how that’s possible when during a rancor chase sequence you can literally just walk away and grab coffee without pausing and be right where you left off.  The entire time I’m just waiting for the cutscenes to stop and the game to start…and it never does.

It’s like those rides at universal studios where you are just watching a movie screen in auditorium seats that shake.  If you find those things exciting then maybe you’ll like this, but if you're like me and find those kinds of rides beyond boring then you’ll be bored here too.

I spent $9 on the 3 episode package and somehow I still manage to feel ripped off.

review_title: Closed Captions for a deaf developer
one_reviews_text:
Love this VR but got stuck because I am a deafie. (Will update review after fix)
 
Fantastic game, but one big flaw for me as a deafie -- there is no closed captioning or subtitles.

A very clever way to do it is the way Red Matter does it -- wrist mounted caption screen or subtitle screen.     This is superior to floating subtitles/captions, which are not realistic/nauseating in VR.

Real-world deaf people already use an app called "Live Transcribe" on android phones to caption real-life.  So this would just be a VR version of real life.  And there could be a backscroll feature if we miss dialogue, and maybe a "screenglow" effect coming from the bottom edge if we aren't lifting our wrists to read captions -- some of us might understand what's going on but only need to glance at captions when we need to. Kind of like a "pip boy" but Star Wars style.

Hello! Deaf gamer here. I need subtitles. Please?

The best subtitle systems are the "Republque VR"-style gentle floats, or the "Red Matter"-style wrist mounted pipboy equivalent.

I wasted money on this game because I didn't know it did not have subtitles.  The Oculus Store does not inform whether a game has subtitles or not.

Oculus Store gets docked a star because it does not have a "Subtitles: Yes/No" field like SteamVR does. I heard through a friend that some group at Gallaudet University (deaf university) is considering a lawsuit to Oculus to humbly request Oculus to make a minor change to Oculus Store (a Subtitles Yes/No checkbox) to get them to at least tell deaf gamers whether a VR game has subtitles or not.

(P.S. I run a website called Blur Busters / Test UFO, and I am a software developer, so I am technically literate as a deafie)

There are solutions that keeps captions/subtitles without breaking immersion -- for some of us. Can you add optional wrist-mount closed captioning, pretty please, ILM?

review_title: Lacking in a lot of ways
one_reviews_text:
I 99%ed episode 1 before playing this one - I wanted to get good at the lightsaber fighting before I continued, because I wanted an epic experience. Episode 1 felt a little short and low budget, but I was incredibly excited to see what they improved when they weren't rushing the first episode out the door.

Lightsaber duels in episode one, both in the dojo and story, were engaging and skillful. In this episode lightsabers are nearly unsuable. Enemy blades go through yours, and it endlessly reminds me I must hold my lightsaber "still and vertical to block" where ep 1 encouraged parrying & counter attacking. Here it seems less about physically blocking the enemy blade and more about whether the game thinks you're holding your lightsaber in some predefined "blocking" position.

The force ability doesn't feel great - in order to do anything, you have to grab things, pull them toward you, and then fling them away. Something a foot from your face, you still have to pull toward you, even after it's floating. If you don't pull toward you, it just floats in place. In the dojo the force is a magic kill button that destroys 2+ enemies per fling and it's so much more useful than actually dueling your opponents that I wonder why you ever would. especially when combat is so broken.

Even throwing your lightsaber, something I dreamed about in the previous lightsaber dojo, is just annoying - it happens anytime you brush the grip button. If you throw it far enough away at an upward angle, there is some drop over time, so I had like 5 minutes of fun throwing it against the far wall. You can dribble your lightsaber like a basketball.

On top of gameplay, the story is *maybe* 20 minutes long, and has nowhere near the variety or engaging environments of ep 1. As noted by other reviews, you essentially stand in place for 99% of it. Also, 99% of it is you standing there or waving your hands at things - no door "puzzles", tools, or interactions besides throwing rocks.

review_title: as game so so, as theme park movie great
one_reviews_text:
If i'd rate this as a game, it would at best get a B- to C from me. Looked at as traditional game, it would be too short, too often block your free movement, just has no challenge at all in story mode (light saber dojo mode has challenge and is more like a traditional game mode).
But after playing the episodes some, it became clear to me that this is not intended to be a game in the traditional sense at all. This is intended to be a fan fantasy fullfillment theme park experience, and as that, it is pretty great, if not excellent.
Graphics and Audio are in a class of their own, very few VR and non VR games and movies come close to this production quality level.
The story and duration is short for usual game standards, but not too short at all when looked at as cinema movie or theme park film.
Basically it is one cinematic moment after the other, never longer than 3-5 minutes doing the same thing. Like as if they made a checklist of what type of Star Wars big cinematic moments could we all have in there, and then they added them all and put one after the other every few minutes. There is a story, with some a bit cheesy worn out moments, some great moments, but to me since i could not stray far from the path nor have branching story choices and the scenery and tasks change constantly, it felt more like the story is there to have a reason to move you from one great Star Wars set piece to another than a world and story one explores freely.
So yeah, if you're looking for a game with constant free movement, challenge etc (in the main story mode, too, not "just" in lightsaber dojo), then you may be disappointed. If you  want a great Star Wars theme park experience, this is hands down the best thing one can have in that field at home right now and really pretty amazing if one thinks about being able to have a theme park experience on this very high visuals, audio and immersion level at home now.
Extra props for the sidekick droid which adds a lot of charm.

review_title: Great experience marred by movement bugs
one_reviews_text:
I enjoy this property a lot! The first episode was brilliant experience, and the moment in this one where you finally wield [spoiler] and [spoiler] at the same time is a fantastic moment of power.
However, I had two major movement glitches during my playthrough that required reloads in order to overcome. For a 45min experience, this is difficult to wave away. Additionally, I never had time to explore the environment, as every time you walk forward it throws you into the next narrative sequence.
I understand the need to help newbie VR players through the experience at the contractually mandated narrative pace: Star Wars is not an IP you can neccessarily deliver off-brand. However, I would appreciate an alternate mode where you have more control over the pace: and possibly less restrictive movement? I miss sprinting, especially in the [spoiler] encounter.
Finally, the force powers are pretty awesome, however they still feel a little clunky. I feel it could be a little sharper, and be more dependent on your hand position (have some rotate control). It would not make a significant difference to the gameplay, but it would increase that feeling of power.
This has elements of a great experience, and I am looking forward to seeing the last episode. However, until the shackles are taken off, I am going to return this, as I don't feel like the restrictions are worth going through a second time.
Edit: Tried the Training Room, this was very fun. The force powers are enjoyable to use here. Wish the lightsaber throw was available in the main game! Still not worth it for me until you get more freedom in the main campaign.

However, the force controls were a little hard to understand at first, and as soon as I learned them combat became rediculously easy, to the point where the lightsaber is unnecessary. This episode also felt much shorter than the first one. 

Honestly, despite these flaws, this series has so far been one of the best and most immersive cinematic experiences I've ever had in VR. We NEED more games like this! I can only hope they improve for the third episode.

review_title: But the dojo in this one is sooo good!
one_reviews_text:
After having a blast with part one i was excited to see this one in the store so i bought it right away. In part two you'll be left off at the same place the first one ended. And i think thats a nice touch. But. Like many others reviewing this game the story part/experience is rather lacking in variety. The first one had these grand open spaces interesting change of scenery, this one is based in a dark cave underground with very dark scenes. Some of them where just pitch black with voiceover... i dont get why. Also extended periods of blacklevels like this does not look that good on rift s imho.  But, its all about the force in this one, and i get that it had to teach you the ways of the force before part 3 so, in all fairness maybe it had to be more darker this time around.  AND yeah using the force to grab stuff/enemies feels really good, thats a lifelong dream for someone who's into starwars. Interaction with objects and climbing is present but not on the same scale or variety as part one.

But all in all, i would recommend it just for the dojo because the dojo in this one is something else, force grab with one hand, throw lightsaber at enemies and retrieve it with the force. Its like part one but you feel more free, not waiting for the enemies attack, its more about precision in the throwing aspect.

review_title: A great arcade game, an ok story mode
one_reviews_text: The story continues but only lasts around 20-30 minutes with some dissapointing gameplay, on the ohter hand the Dojo is amazing and offers so much replayability. I love the Dojo and it's mechanics and how you can choose to play whatever way youo want, whether you rely on the force or you lightsaber or the traps set around the room, way better than the first. Even though it's a little dissapointing I still higly reccomend this.

this felt like a big let down after the promise the first chapter showed. This just has less of everything, with the entire experience in murky underground caves. force powers are added, but honestly i dont find that all that exciting, considering its exactly how the oculus home menu works anyway! other than that, nothing new. infact less of everything. no lightsaber duels outside of the dojo, very little action at all.  episode 3 had better look amazing, or my star wars VR journey ends here. not going to pay another £7 for a dojo skin.

review_title: Only a fan cuz its Star wars
one_reviews_text: The campaign was way too short less than 30 minutes, half that time you we're just standing there! You don't even do any free roaming you're usually stuck every 5 seconds you walk foward. Not worth the $10 ... The dojo isn't that good either. I want to play more but might return it. I'll just go back to the first episode. Was looking forward to using Force abilities, and hope to use blasters one day.
My first experance with a lightsaber in VR an i love it

There was only 1 hour of story and its not even that great of a story. The only thing that saves it is that it is star wars. They don't make me care at all about the "good guys". The story telling is dry and incomplete.

Ever wonder what it it like to be IN Star Wars instead of just watching it on tv? Holy crap this VR production is good! If you are even remotely close to wanting to experience the day in the life of a Jedi this is it! Hands down you must BUY BUY BUY!!! (I wish I could give this 10 stars)
The story is mediocre, but pick this one up for the lightsaber dojo. Throwing your lightsaber through a droid and catching just in time to block a block a blow from another droid is magical.

review_title: A quirky, quick Star Wars Dungeon Crawl
one_reviews_text:
Honestly for the same price as the previous episode I am very disappointed. For 10$ the previous episode had a story that took at least an hour to complete, big, if not quick, fights, and enough star wars widgets and gidgets to make you squeal with excitement!

What do we get for 10$ this time? A lot of Darth Vader being mad, the ability to pick up rocks off the ground (yes, this includes the lightsaber, it's made of metal and a shiny bit on top) and a few forgettable droid fights which (although now feel more impactful with the new procedural slicing system in place) still feel more like a stand in one place and let things attack you first sort of fight rather than a get up close and stab things through sort of fight. It's just not entertaining, especially for the price. And I know the big sell for this episode is the force ability, but if we're being real here, it's SUPER janky. Half the time it picks up something out of view when I have my hand almost directly pointed at the same object, and even after completing the campaign and spending 20-30 minutes in the Dojo I still have no idea what motion brings things closer to me versus throwing them into a wall or (god forbid) another enemy. the selection of objects takes too long for force powers, enemies have a HUGE time span of invulnerability when emerging from cover (I'm talking like, I've tried to pick them up about ten times before they allow me to, which feels extremely agonizing, especially for a player who is just told "you have promise". Like, let me grab the bots now or never. Plain and simple.

And the dungeon is so dark, even if I had more time to explore I couldn't! Peering into the dungeons (tomb, library, etc), there are some amazing assets here, but I can't see any of it! I feel like a jedi padawan using his lightsaber as a torch instead of a weapon, trying to feel my way through a murky sith soup.

Was kinda fun tho. 

Also you can't use the cool new lightsaber in the Dojo without unlocking it first.

Getting to use force powers should feel awesome, sadly it boils down to picking very specific objects and throwing them. The campaign is very short and at times I didn't have a clue what's happening during combat. Seeing more of Vader was cool, but short lived. Not really an improvement from the first episode.

Not worth a $5 footlong from subway in 2010. It took 30 minutes of my time and everything was dark as hell and it was even worse since LCD panels on the valve index don't do well with mostly black screens. In a nutshell. Youre some Mustafarian descendent and you follow vader because only your blood can unlock their tombs to obtain a 50lbs kyber crystal that can be used to leech life from a planet to bring back one life. That is why Mustafar is a barren volcanic planet because the original user failed and wouldve blown up the planet and herself to bring her husband back. The crystal was later used to contruct the deathstar laser. Of course the game doesn't go through all of this unless you're familiar with the movies youre out of luck.
I loved Episode I of Star Wars: Vader Immortal, but part two was a huge dissapointment, yes I want a third to finish the ending, but we need a multiple hour storyline to hook the fans!

Visuals and story are excellent again, but I can't help to feel they could've done so much more with using the Force. Was hoping for a bit more build-up to using it instead of 'You have the Force now, glhf'. Honestly it feels like this part should've come for free with the previous episode considering the length and limited gameplay.
bit short but when will get episod three verry good game.

I was expecting some more puzzles with the force abilities that would make the game a bit longer. More fights with lightsabers that would help distinguish when to use the force and when to use the lightsaber. That being said it met my expectations. I hope that in the next one they add a force lightening ability. However, in terms of the story line the character is relatively new to the force so the things we can do in the game seem a little advanced compared to the training Vader gives you. The first game gives you a great intro, the second is all about the force, it didn't really add a whole lot to the story. If only we were given choices that put us on different paths! I think this would add replayability of the game. I think a force shield would be nice since that is really the first thing both Jedi and with learn in combat training. Regardless of my opinion or others it is a great experience Everytime Vader is in the game. Great job on the dojo!!!

On its own Episode II is undeniably a 5-star experience, but when compared to Episode I, it doesn't fully live up to my expectations.
You indeed get the promised Force, and can use it to grab and move stuff from afar. However with very minimal UI, aiming is a bit difficult, because where the game is actually aiming may differ from where you think you are aiming. This takes time to get used to.
Once you get good at using the Force, though, it becomes overpowered. You can easily pick up one enemy and slam it into another, taking two of them out in one hit. This is way more efficient than using a Lightsaber, making the latter more of a defensive weapon. The game also allows you to throw and recall your Lightsaber, as well as activate traps, but all of them feel like jokes compared to the overwhelming power of the Force.
Although the Dojo now has more rounds and throws more types of enemies at you, it doesn't actually provide more variety when all you do is grab, throw, grab, throw. It may get more challenging in later rounds when enemies can resist the Force for a while, but the early rounds are definitely boring.
10 mins into game you have to climb some stairs which are about 5 feet infront of you and  you cant continue do you ever test these games

The first episode was borderline when it came to value, but episode 2 is even shorter.

While it's visually nice (and one of the locations had a bit of Batman VR vibe when you enter an enourmous cavern), it's actually a quite dark experience for the most part - quite annoying considering how short it is (maybe 30 minutes).

If you liked the dojo from the first one, then that's back and that's where it might make up its value to you. If you're here for the story though, then you might feel a bit short-changed.

Like another review here, I suffered the same issue with blocking (or being unable to sometimes) in the dojo that wasn't there in Episode 1.

Just had to come back and update the review to a 2. It really bugged me thinking about it. $10 for 30 minutes (I'm not counting the dojo padding which is just basically more of the same) is just not cutting it with me.

If they don't put more effort into Episode 3, then this deal is getting worse all the time...

review_title: Aren't you a little short for a...
one_reviews_text:
It was a lot of fun but pretty short.  Right when I thought it was going to get started it ended.  One day, when these are all put together this will be a great game (That I would even pay 30 dollars for).  I just don't like the pauses.
Also, on a Rift CV1 there is some weird phenomenon where dark areas (like the walls in the distance) sort of lag.  I wish the devs noticed and changed their brightness/color usage/I don't know but it's glaring and obvious.  I think it's some sort of OLED weirdness. I saw it on both CV1 and Quest.

review_title: Not a great successor to Episode 1
one_reviews_text:
For the second episode in this series, it didn't build much upon the story. The only significant difference gameplay wise is the addition of Force Powers, which felt under utilized in the story. 

The Dojo on the other hand has a few interesting uses for Force Powers, triggering traps, throwing saber. Sadly there's no different arenas like the first episode so far because of adding the traps and the rewards so far seem to be the same for the saber as Episode 1.

All in all the Dojo is fun but if you're just interested in the story Episode 2 is not that great imo

Overall very good production. From the sound, the graphics, the voice acting etc. it is all very engrossing. It's just far too short. Seems like there should be another 30 minutes worth of content to make the purchase worth it. Everything also feels a little too much like a tech demo. I hope for the next installment they take off the reigns and have a much longer campaign mode.
This is the best Episode of them all!

The episode was short but awesome and worth every penny! Don't let the short duration of the story deter from buying this game, there is plenty of replay value with the Jedi dojo,  and It's fun AF! I spent three hours straight in the Dojo and still haven't completed all the challenges. The new force powers and light saber throw really make the combat feel more complete. The unlockable light sabers are nice as well. I can't wait for episode three! I hope we get at least 10 episodes!

The main thing I wanted to comment on is how short Vader is, which bugged me in the first one and is even more noticeable here. He should definitely tower over us and not be shoulder to shoulder with a normal person. This is the easiest thing to have gotten right!

To give my other impressions: it felt a bit pedestrian this time, like we've seen all the tricks in the bag and it's unlikely to be as varied as the first episode again. The story is unfolding with its fairly contrived ancient history of Mustafar told almost entirely as exposition.

Personally would have much preferred a C3P0 or K2SO-type sidekick than the L337 type we got. 

This episode featured quite a bit of walking about in caves. Not much effort goes in to a narrative reason why you'd stand still in one spot and solve everything. Then things happen as a series of Quicktime events, you may generally fail to quite understand what they're getting at with how they imagine you'll move rocks around, but you'll get through the level unharmed regardless.

It's starting to feel like you could watch a few episodes on Youtube to cover the story and if the Dojo is the actual game, then the last episode's Dojo is probably the one to buy. You'd miss out mostly on the walking around in caves and a few jump scares as a set piece happens to the environment that you have no influence over.

review_title: Fun, but with a game breaking bug
one_reviews_text:
I couldn't complete the story because of a game breaking bug at the end involving climbing ("Move back into area" even though I couldn't move). Restarting checkpoint didn't help. What I played of the story was cool, but the controllers kept vibrating because it wanted me to use the Force on nothing in particular (this happened throughout my experience, from the first time you can use the Force). It's also a pretty short story mode, lasting probably 30-40 minutes.

The dojo is a lot of fun though, and with Force powers you can do SO much more than in Episode 1. It's really a treat, and fulfills that childhood fantasy of throwing things at enemies while you block blaster bolts with your saber. Awesome stuff.

I can't see a way to contact the developer directly, but please, fix the bugs in the story mode and this will easily be a 5 star game. There's not much here, but what there is is pretty fun. It just needs to, you know, work properly.

review_title: Wanted to love it, but just can't...
one_reviews_text:
Episode 1 blew me away, I had only just got the rift and it was my first purchase, and WOW. The scale was amazing, with the start destroyer, the hanger bay etc. Only slight frustration was the way it let you go through walls and you "left the play area". 
(I mean, Lone Echo has collision control, so does Red Matter, so really?)
There was also a ton of interacting with stuff, cutting things down, climbing and so I was really looking forward to more of the same. 
Instead it just feels like a rushed walking sim. It still looks great, and yeah, throwing rocks is kinda fun, but it just was no way near as immersive and fun as part 1. The story was also stupidly short. I know its only €10, and it is still just about worth it, but when I think of the likes of Loe Echo, Hellblade or Moss, all of which I paid 30 quid for and gave me HOURS of enjoyment, 10 quid for 20 minutes just stings a little. Hopefully they will one day release a proper full length 20+ hour game, I would happily shell out 40 or 50 quid or so for that. 
Pros: Fun chucking stuff about. Looks good. Dojo is good...
Cons. Short, not much interaction. 
Worth it? Yeah, just about.

It's okay but it's nowhere as good as the first episode. The first episode had stormtroopers, spaceships, it felt you were really in Star Wars, the very first time you picked up a lightsaber was absolutely epic!
Bit this one is completely different, an underground voyage where you spend a big chunk of your time killing flying bugs. It's okay but comparing this to the first episode I finished it feeling pretty disappointed.

Very poor  episode compared to Ep1, vey little in the way of progressing the story line and very short, with what feels to be a rushed continuation of the story which is always almnost 'on rails'.  Continuity also broken where markers were placed in the game area to continue the story. Overall a disapointing experience.

review_title: Still adds up to best series in VR
one_reviews_text: While episode II is a little bit more repetitive and less engaging in the story line, the Dojo is MUCH better, the force controls feel slightly laggy and can be a little hard to aim when picking things up, but could be used for some amazingly cool stuff in the third episode. Overall, still one of the better VR games around and a great addition to the series, but the story was a little lacking. Looking forward to number 3!

The ep are a little too short the story feels like it is getting rushed into things i finished it within 15 min or 30 at a push. 

Gameplay is great.
The force is a little buggy you have to point instead of putting ur palm to the object which will feel alot better/look like the movies exc.
Graphics are awesome!

After playing the first part I had high hopes for this. Now I am disappointed, it is even less than the first game was. If the first part was a demo then this is only a sneak peek - but not a full game. In the first chapter you are in space, in the castle, you can see the hills and the lava rivers of mustafar, it has a cave and quite a few surprises. And this second one? Caves and a not-that-easy-to-kill monster. Dojo is nice but the only reason I paid money is the single player part, because that is official canon and that is painfully short and does not really move forward the story. And there are bugs... maybe it was rushed too much. Yes, it is Star Wars. Yes, it is nice. Yes, they are milking the fans. The only way I can forgive this if the third (final) part will be epic with much more locations, twists, surprises and diverse tasks. Maybe shooting with a laser pistol?
 Maybe flying a stolen TIE fighter and escaping from Vader? A filght simulator "dojo"? Let us hope the Force will be stronger next time.

review_title: It's really cool and all but...
one_reviews_text:
I really liked it. Fighting the Rancor is cool and all but, I just want to stab some stormtrooers. I would just say its a little underwhelming. I think the spectical and the general feeling of the first one just feels more like star wars. 

The story is still very fun and interesting. I can't tell you to skip this one or anything, but I don't think ill be putting the 4-5 hours into dojo or replaying the main story like I did with the first episode.

review_title: Awesome Game To Help Channel The Force
one_reviews_text: I love how this game allows us to both use the force and a lightsaber to defeat our enemies.

If you loved the first one, you'll definetly love this one too. The new force power is really cool and the fights are as good as the ones in the first episode. But the experience is really too short, like less than two hours.

Like the first episode, the dojo is the main part of the game and is really enjoyable !

I finished the story in about 40 minutes. Sadly it doesn't have as much combat as the first episode and exposition is briefer.
BUT, now that you have Force powers, the dojo is way more fun. While the story teaches you how to Force pull/push, it doesn't teach you that YOU CAN SABER THROW!
Another nitpick is that Force pull sometimes feels unresponsive in frantic situations. To me it feels like I'm doing the gesture correctly, but it doesn't register on the object.

The experience just as Episode 1 was amazing. Couple of parts where I jumped too.

But seriously... 35 minutes? I get it... it's a 'experience'... but 35 minutes?!?!?! No.... Its not worth $15AUD for 35mins....  It felt artificially short on purpose. There was no reason why you couldn't have reached your army for the big reveal... just poor value.

tldr; great on its own, but not as good as the first.
As it was an immediate continuation of the first episode there wasn't really a need to retell the original story however as it goes along you'll notice this is really more of an action episode.  I'm totally fine with that however if it's going to be action heavy I wish it would have given me more of it.
The only reason I dinged it a star was because I think the force power mechanic wasn't terribly accurate.  When I would force grab something and throw it it turned out to be the item next to it.  It was difficult to say the least. 
Still a great next chapter in the story and I can't wait until the next one!

review_title: Not as good as the first, but good
one_reviews_text: I've given this 4 stars as for £8 you get a continuation of the great first game, but it is about 5 minutes shorter, which leads to an unimpressive 35 minutes. The story just could have been longer on this one. Still very enjoyable, and the Lightsaber Dojo now lets you use the force. The lightsaber is easier than the first one, but very fun.

review_title: Taster as before, but it's not the end..
one_reviews_text: It's a beautifully made piece of cinematics and you are the part of it. You can try the capabilities of the Rift. Yes, the story is "short" again, and you'll know the saga continues. :) The controls and interactions are well made, but you have to get used to it...no you can't, the story ends till that. BUT there is a Jedi training mode where you will be tested. Basically here you can learn all the Jedi stuff. I gave 4 star for the short story mode, but the price is therefore well positioned. ...Oh and there is a 1 minute blackout where nothing happens only Vader panting a lot. :)

review_title: Fun dojo, but the end? SO BAD
one_reviews_text:
OMG the ending. It's a giant Rancor. I have a lightsaber. How can this not turn out to be the most epic thing ever? It should lunge at me and I should, at some point after dying like 20 times, figure out that I need to leap into it's mouth and jab my lightsaber up into it's soft pallete and into it's brain. That's how this SHOULD have ended. Spoiler alert (JK - when you actually play it you'll experience spoiled...) the end they gave us? A pile of rando red shirts come out of somewhere (nowhere) and start shooting the thing? Come on? Who are these guys? Do I care about the Mustafar and these wierdos? I've only met 2 of them and one of them betrayed his whole people. Frankly, I'd as soon cut these jokers down and I'd cut down that grumpy Rancor. At least the Rancor is a big neat critter who's hungry, these squirmy Mustafarians (yah man) I just can't get behind.

If it wasn't for the dojo, I'd be mad. However, if I really think about it if I just  bought the dogo for $10 - I'd be mad. You know what? I'm mad. 

Fix the ending in the next one, I certainly WON'T be buying it w/o reading the reviews first. You're not shearing this sheep again with lazy storytelling.

As far as I enjoy the combat, i.e. using the Force and the lightsaber, the game is even shorter than the first one. I guess the Dojo will make up for that.
P.S. Near the end occassionally I could only hear sounds, but all blackout. I have to select the chapter again and then it's ok after.

There is something special about using a light saber and the force in VR and I would give it 5 stars if it was a more fleshed out game but the story only takes about 40  mins to finish so your really just paing the money dojo 2.  The story mode is fun but like I said far too short, I think even shorter than the first one.

Audio working fine everywhere (dash, oher titles) but in vader immortal not... I was tried everything without success... Where can be a problem? Thanks VoDaCZ

Game is amazing but really short, much than previous part... Next time i dont pay for next part, because its most expensive and short game... Its amazing SW game but not for this price!!!

review_title: Short but the Dojo is good
one_reviews_text: The story mode is just walking around caves with Vader for a bit, standing around feeling awkward, fighting off a some beasties and then FIN. Pretty short and definately not as good as part one. However I'm loving the Dojo II. Probably worth the 7.99 alone. Lots more unlockables and is challenging without being unfair. The addition of using force powers is great, I just wish they implemented it a bit better in the story. If you're a Star Wars fan then this game is a must.

When I get to the crystal part when I get to the top it takes a while for the sentinels to spawn and the characters didn't react to the sentinels and I looked this game up on youtube and the characters react to it! Please fix this so i can play the game more!

review_title: about 30 mins to complete. but its 7.99
one_reviews_text: bit dissapointed really. though be abit more cool things to do but 90% of the story is just chucking rocks and explosives!! bought both of the games today and im quite let down tbh being a huge starwars fan. 1st one is better,  would rather been able to walk and fight at the same time and explore the places ive seen on the movies. the concept is really cool and do think this game is good i do, BUT could of been something absolutely amazing. its far too short thinking about it think took me 30mins to complete, there's 0 interactive things to do and that what make VR FUN! just got bit boring chucking rocks 24/7 and same as the wave round onit now... also no clue how many rounds there is but the scenery is the same so got abit boring after 2 hours looking at the same wall and took me longer to get to wave 20 then it did to complete the game lol. could of improved on the wave side of things, really good game but im let down like i said. hire me please lol

review_title: South paws will have trouble in this.
one_reviews_text: It starts off nice, cool dark audio then with the sinister glow with vader. Teaching me how to use the force. Trouble is though, if you are left handed, be ready to spam it. Same with the right hand. Secondly, if you use the light saber with the left hand, more then all of the boss attacks are meant for right handed people the way it moves. And above all, you can't join vader, not even to choose to give him the relic. That is really unfair, you tease to be able to join the dark side. Even get to kill the bug creatures. Yet, you can't kill or force crush the one who gives it to vader. That and way too short. Half the play time, so should be half the price. Or at least delayed until you give me the proper mini game. Two stars for not letting me be a sith.

review_title: excelent game just a little short
one_reviews_text: Excelent game epic even, my only issue was it felt a little short. put Z0-E3 is now one of my fav droids in star wars almost on par with R2-D2.  Your not properly told how to use the controls but when you get the hang of it its great and works really well. also more combat in the first one but combat in this game is more versitile

I haven't even touched the story yet but a lot has been added to the dojo to make it more interactive. In ep1 your non-lightsaber hand was pretty useless where now you've got force powers. Plus the traps, additional enemies and lightsaber throwing are so much more fun.

I had this problem with episode 1 where I couldn't climb because by left hand wouldn't grab anything. Wish the devs would fix this bug so I could properly play the game. Would love to give 5 stars but this just kills it for me

I enjoyed killing darth vader and it was a bit sad that my droid died but atleast i killed vader and the emperor!

Joking lol but it was maybe a little short but overall it was pretty cool! I'm dying for episode 3. If they live up to what they said in the game it will be AWESOME!

The story mode was great with the added force power, but just like part 1 it is very short. A canon story is cool and all, but in the end it is the lightsaber dojo you are really paying for. And yes, it is great.

Love these episodes. They Look fantastic, the music and voice acting is excellent, and there are a great mix of VR actions: Climbing, force levitation, lightsaber combat. These are the Star Wars games I dreamed of long ago in a childhood that is now pretty far away...

This is pretty obviously an inbetween episode to setup for what comes next. 

Dojo II makes it pretty clear just how amazing combat can feel with both the force on your side and lightsabre in hand. I hope they can bring it all together in the third episode!
Should last longer, but beside of that is amazing, one of the best vr games of the history

Yeah I was expecting something at least on part with Part 1 (which I found cool, but many room for improvement). They charged the same price as Part 1 and the product is like 33% as good. SO buyer beware!

Felt short, it's nice to see the story progressing but the gameplay took a step back. While they introduced Force powers they don't give you much opportunity to use them and the gameplay overall feels clumsy. Bigger install than the first but felt like less content

review_title: Amazing just like the first one
one_reviews_text: The story is short, 40 minutes gameplay (kinda like ep. I.). But the dojo became even better, than before. Using the Force is very, very satisfying :). If you liked ep. I. you should buy this. I miss some lightsabers (e.g. Kylo Ren's) from the rewards tough.
A bit worst than the first episode but I believe the third one will be better

I'll keep this review as short as the game/experience was: its pretty good (although part I in my view was better), but equally short. So no 5 stars this time (but still good value for money, especially when you consider the dojo part).
I think this is one of the best virtual reality experiences that I've ever had. This is a lot better than part one and feels more realistic. Definitely deserves to be played.

Dissapointing follow-up to Episode 1.  I was expecting more.  Not sure if it is worth $10.  Not much to do but watch the great visuals, and throw rocks.  If Episode III isn't any better, I'll be quitting the series.  Guess I'll have to find out?

I bought it minutes after it was out and I loved every second of it! The Dojo 2 is wayyyy better than the first Vader Immortal. With the force powers you feel more like a jedi then ever! The story is short as normal but it was good.

Did leave 5 stars at first but the dojo is buggy when the robots use a power attack to attack me half the time it goes right through my lightsaber when i clearly blocked it:).. now, looking forward to streamimg part 1 and 2 simotainiously!
10 Euro for 20 min of story!?

I’ve waited so long for this to get released. Only to release there’s 30 minutes of game play, and a lot less story than part 1. I was truly disappointed to see the credits rolling after such a short time.

really short, way too short, i know there is the forge but come on, it's half shorter that the first one, next time what, the episode 3 will be 15 min long, at least it's not 30$ game but still 12$ for so little almost feal like a rip off

review_title: What a let down after a promising P1
one_reviews_text:
Shorter and with less light saber fight than the part 1.

one_reviews_text: For 10 bucks this is way too short - yes it´s well done, as the first part was, but the whole episode II is to run from one short stop to another use the force (push pull) a few times and then get to the endfight. This episode starts right where you left off in episode 1. Story is shorter and there isn't that much combat in this one. There is the addition of the force grab/throw, which is actually much better utilized in the lightsaber dojo than in the story mode. The lightsaber dojo is a lot more fun in this version because of the force powers (throwing your lightsaber is the absolute best) and the new mechanic of using the environment against your enemies. I'm giving it a 4 star because I was hoping for a more substantial story in this one. Hopefully episode 3 is longer and has more combat in it. Regardless, this does a great job at hyping up the next episode.

I expected the story campaign to be the same length as the first, but it felt a bit shorter. Considering this game's story is considered canon there is an interesting revelation surrounding a mysterious character further focused on in this episode that I sense will be a clue regarding Star Wars Episode IX The Rise of Skywalker.

The force powers are super clunky and half the time non-responsive which is frustrating. I sometimes had to hold my hand longer at the enemy or aim my palms higher to get the force lock on them. People in my stream said it just looked janky and not well balanced.

Once you get a lightsaber the game shines again like Episode 1. If only the force power controls felt more responsive. The dojo is still solid as before and when the force powers actually work when you want them too it feels even better.

review_title: Good but too short and simple
one_reviews_text:
I really liked the first episode and I liked this one too but it didn't surprise me the same way the first did. It's way too short, even more than the first one (around 35') and not much happens. It looks fantastic, controls are good and using the force is very cool but not much more to it, there is less climbing, less interaction and a little less of everything. I was expecting more for a second episode.
Another thing I don't like is the fact that every episode is installed separately, you cannot play both episodes in a row without quitting one episode first and starting the next as if it was another game.
It's also unbelievable that being a Star Wars title there is no support for other languages, not even captions. 
Still  looking forward to Ep. 3 and still dreaming of a real full-length Star Wars game like this; the mechanics are great, it just needs the content.

As good as the first on the campaign with a slightly more complex Dojo thanks to the force-powers.  However that comic relief robot, can we please just kill her?  I also, while far less, still got "please move back to your world" message once in a while, this is not needed, our VR software comes with baked in chaperone systems.

I like the storyline, so for that the “campaign” is enjoyable even if there’s not a lot of meat on the bone. But it was not working well... when I tried turning, at least half the time it would rotate left instead of right. Same problem on the Rift S version and I haven’t had that problem in other games. The dojo however is awesome. I found it dull in the first episode but much more interesting this time around. Ultimately though doesn’t feel much different than Robo Recall, so if  not for the Star Wars gloss it would not be all that engaging. It’s a shame you can’t move around the arena and pick up more objects than just rocks and enemies. Still, for the price it’s not bad.

I don't understand some of the negative reviews on here. Yes, it's only 40 minutes long, but it is an incredible and magical experience for only $9. When you go to a movie theatre to watch a 1.5 hour film, you don't complain at the end about replay value. And this is way more immersive than any movie. A ton of hard work was put into this and we should be grateful for it. Plus the dojo arena for fighting creatures feels really fun and has some replay value.
